target_title: Confirmation message when changes on user-defined large number of files

note.body:
Indeed (Keep It Simple, I agree), but here this is just one option to protect database from accidental unwanted big changes (user mistake). If that implementation is too "big" (or complex, or whatever reason) change for the developers (!), then just close this issue stating that this won't be implemented for some reason you will mention.

It already happened to me several times (you know, being on "Photos" rather on the last import, then CTRL+A, tagging all the "last import" pictures). Then suddenly see that this was done on dozens thousands of pictures rather than on couple of them. That's why I opened that enhancement case.

target_title: Confirmation message when changes on user-defined large number of files

note.body: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rRvmS0mABC0

target_title: Confirmation message when changes on user-defined large number of files

note.body:
I do not think this is very complex to implement in Edition > Preferences:
1. Input value (by default 500 maybe?) for number of files that will change to popup a confirm message.
2. Enable or disable tick-box for enabling or not the popup warning message.

Message could be like "You are about to modify more than 500 files, are you sure you want to proceed?" Yes/No.

That's it.

target_title: Viewer - Can't scroll through images in a directory

note.body:
Not by 99% of users who have no idea what a "sandbox" is. It's useless like this, I would have stopped using it if someone hadn't told me how to bodge it. 
All it needs is to add this to the manifest:
```
finish-args:
  - --filesystem=home
```
That might make the Flatpak appear as 'Unsafe' to Flathub, but since it is (I think) Gnome software, I imagine it would be possible to sort that out.

target_title: Viewer - Can't scroll through images in a directory

note.body: Pretty much expected when having the sandbox, though

Comment for translation about face recognition

note.body: The string in the initial report is indeed fine. However, `"Face"` in `src/searches/SearchBoolean.vala` can be a bit confusing as it’s on its own, with no other face related string around it. So I would add a comment that says “Translators: the face of someone” to ensure translators know what this is about.

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body:
that's quite interesting to know, thanks

the Sony A6700 has four choices overall when options are combined
* jpg only
* hif only
* jpg + raw
* hif + raw

I've not had it that long, so I only recently discovered this shotwell problem.

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body: Thanks, but I am trying to move away from handling several image loading libraries myself, possibly moving to glycin at some point. For the current Shotwell incarnation there is no way to get a non-rgb surface to render to anyway.

target_title: Include many useful infos in the basic pane

note.body:
First, thanks a lot. However, the elephant in the room is: This information is useful for you to have ready all the time, but others would maybe like to have other information there all the time. (No, the answer to that is not "make it configurable")

TBH I do not even know how the exposure information made it into basic information in the first place, it is weirdly off from the rest of what is in there.

I'd probably prefer a better structured extended information pane and the resize bug fixed (If the extended pane is resizable, the image display sometimes disappears below the pane after opening it).

target_title: Include many useful infos in the basic pane

note.body: From what I can tell at first glance it should also be able to be merged into master but my linux distribution still has 0.32.x so this is what I worked with

this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body:
Ok, then you're probably out of luck because the gdb-pixbuf API only supports the RGB colorspace and no tiling. Also no access to thumbnails.

Might be worth to consider a direct libheif integration in the future.
Let me know if you need any support for that.

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body: FWIW, shotwell uses the gdk-pixbuf loader from the libheif repository, not code that I wrote.

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body:
BTW: also make sure that you use a thumbnail image stored in the HEIF if you do not need the full resolution. The example image attached in this issue has three thumbnails as reported by `heif-info`:
```
image: 6192x4128 (id=5), primary
  tiles: 2x2, tile size: 3136x2112
  colorspace: YCbCr, 4:2:2
  bit depth: 10
  thumbnail: 1616x1080
  thumbnail: 320x212
  thumbnail: 160x120
```

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body:
Hello, libheif author here.

It is clear that HEIC is a much more complex format than JPEG and thus also more computationally expensive to decode. As such, this is nothing unexpected.

However, note that in the current `master` branch (upcoming v1.19.0), there have been several enhancements to skip internal color-space conversion steps if possible. You get the fastest decoding speeds if you call `heif_decode_image()` with `heif_colorspace_undefined` and `heif_chroma_undefined`. Then libheif will use the colorspace of the original image and doesn't do any internal colorspace conversions which can slow everything down.

Also note that the upcoming version of libheif has an easy API to read images tile by tile. This can help when you are processing high resolution images. Here is a description of the API:
https://github.com/strukturag/libheif/wiki/Reading-and-Writing-Tiled-Images

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body: libheif bug report: https://github.com/strukturag/libheif/issues/1357

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body:
If you look at that flamegraph, shotwell opening the file is dominated by libheif:

![image](/uploads/a9eb18b74ce70d341611d144ce6bd5b2/image.png)

So, I'd say libheif is not very happy with this kind of HEIF files.

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body: HEIF metadata does not work on fedora 40, known issue, nothing to do with shotwell. JPEG should definitely work, though. (try ctrl-shift-x for the extended information panel)

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body:
I just noticed that Eye Of Mate doesn't show any meta data from a HIF file, whereas it can show EXIF from a JPG. Shotwell doesn't seem to notice meta data from a HIF, nor for EXIF in a JPG.

HIF files should support meta data, it's in the spec.
https://docs.fileformat.com/image/heic/

anyway, that's a different matter.

target_title: this is a libheif problem. Was: using Shotwell to view Sony HEIC/HIF files causes CPU usage to max out

note.body: I see the noticeable slower opening, but not the CPU load. Loupe similarly takes a moment to think about opening the file, and all in all I would be leaning towards libheif, though not sure what EoG would do differently, they all use libheif in the end.

note.body: Hi @magnetic333, thanks for reporting this. Currently this task cannot be handled as it is a catch-all for too many different things. This task cannot be assigned, worked on, the task status cannot be set as there are different things requested. Please only report one problem or request per task. Can you please split this task into separate tasks, and follow the issue reporting guidelines linked from https://handbook.gnome.org/issues.html to provide clear issues how to reproduce some problem somehow? Thanks a lot!

target_title: Import LSF+RAW failure...

note.body:
So dcraw seems to give results without error.

exiv2, however, gives this error when writing to a file:

$ exiv2 -pa PA100414.ORF > $HOME/Downloads/exiv2_PA100414
Error: XMP Toolkit error 201: Error in XMLValidator
Warning: Failed to decode XMP metadata.
$

The file does get created.  It has three readable sections - the first 22
lines or so, then miles of just numbers, then another 20 lines and lots of
numbers, then the last 20 lines.  It's a 6.0Mb file, so I'm not trying to
upload the original, but I trimmed the numbers out so you can see what I'm
talking about. Also, printed it to a PDF, but it will only print the first
13 pages and then quits for some reason.

Let me know what else I can do to help.

[exiv2_PA100414_trimmed](/uploads/30c438a5dedc199101e9281d7c557d95/exiv2_PA100414_trimmed)

[exiv2_PA100414.PDF](/uploads/05686495fc61defca181d495b53447aa/exiv2_PA100414.PDF)

[dcraw_PA100414](/uploads/d3663892021f234bdd209a5c0a8f9551/dcraw_PA100414)

note.body:
It cannot read the ORF file, e.g.

L 13037 2024-10-10 22:14:12 [WRN] Photo.vala:1199: Unable to interrogate photo file /home/family/Pictures/2024/10/10/PA100433.ORF: unpack: Input/output error

Not sure why, though. I tried with OM-1 sample images from the internet on PoP!OS and it seems to be ok.

Can you check if those two programs output anything on those files? (You might need to install them with sudo apt install dcraw exiv2)

1) dcraw -i -v
2) exiv2 -pa
